com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2880754
>the gameplay was way to easy
I've heard that's the case for lower difficulties, but I've only played the game on Critical. If anything, on Critical it's kind of bullshit because arenas are so big and enemies groups so spread out, you most often get killed by shit flying at you from offscreen, which wasn't much of thing in KH1 and KH2. Early-game mob fights devolve into boring hit-and-run tactics and late-game becomes Thundaga spam. Mid to late-game boss fights are mostly fun though.

I really just liked that the game was closer to KH1 and 2 after playing a bunch of spin-offs with the command deck that Osaka Team could never balance, but I didn't like that KH3 got some of the floatiness from BBS and DDD.

>the story was a dumb mess even by kh standards( I blame the dumb gacha and the dumb shit it introduced, that and disney meddling )
I wouldn't say that Chi is a problem itself. I would say the main issue is that KH3 should have come out sooner.

First off, DDD kind of cannibalizes KH3's plot, stuff like Sora meeting Xehanort, True Organization XIII's introduction, or Riku's character arc should have been in 3. It contributes to KH3's weird structure where it lacks any real first act to its plot, it just kind of starts mid-story and you have to played previous games to follow what's going on (which despite what some people say, wasn't the case for KH2 or any previous game except maybe DDD).

Second, all the time it took for KH3 to get made gave time for Nomura and other writers to play around with Chi, leading to them getting antsy about using all this new lore they made and so blew some their load early shoving it in KH3, leading to the feeling like half the game's plot is just set-up for KH4.

In an ideal universe DDD wouldn't exist, Nomura and other KH1 & 2 staff wouldn't have wasted years trying to make Versus XIII, they would have made KH3 around 2012 or so, and then Chi and Dark Road would have been full spin-offs before later KH4 comes out.

name: Anonymous
com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

Granted, a lot of it is smoke and mirrors, which becomes apparent the more you play. The dungeons are insane and the quests all pretty much play out the same way. I can understand why some people get filtered by the graphics, etc. but it’s a really charming game

Oh, and I didn't really use a sorc in my run beyond 1 level of sorc (with cotw), I used MT because MT >>> a pure sorc in that environment. Casts per day mattered a lot more than anything else in a vancian environment that penalized resting, and even better to cut another caster from the lineup by mashing it in with eccli backline cleric, who always had known utility in his prepared slots and was free to spend shitloads of slots on pure blasting. Cutting another caster slot allowed me to fill it with a ranged like ekun and beating the rest constraint even harder.

Attached my casting bar, which doesn't even show all the stupid amounts of spells he could blast with at maximized evocation while still having far more flexibility than even a sorc due to his cleric slots. Not to mention the ability to burn spells to increase DC, although I never had to even use that since I had so many copies of spells to just unload. I had options to change the element which never came up like I thought it would, and burning arc were meta with increased range mainly.

I don't think anyone ever will make a better caster in PKM desu unless it will be me on my later evil necromancy run with an MC MT. That is because boneshatter line has some potential to beat burning arc for single target I believe. Those are controlled fireballs and burning arc which just allow indiscriminate screen clearing in the middle of your party. You could abuse AT and sirroco or w/e back when, but this bastard was king in every casting scenario, utility, and could heal you afterwards to boot.

com:
What are some games you want to recommend? Here's mine, Fuga; Melodies of Steel.

A Turn-based RPG where you battle enemies' war machines while managing resources, resources, health, etc. Your main casts consist of 14 children forced into a war or survival, it's kill or be killed for them.

One of the key features of the game is the "soul cannon," where in order to progress you'll have to sacrifice one of your characters to power their ultimate weapon to defeat the bosses and progress the game.
(The whole game kinda gives off Bokurano vibes for those of you who read it.)

This game was developed by CyberConnect2 and is the 4th installment of the Little Tail Bronx series.

Link to steam page
https://store.steampowered.com/app/1357860/Fuga_Melodies_of_Steel/

And apparently, there's a sequel coming out in 2023.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/2001340/Fuga_Melodies_of_Steel_2/

Also, this game does not have any furry degeneracy shit in it, the developers were more inspired by Miyazaki films.

name: Anonymous
sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

>>2876501
Because tons of people have never once in their lives played actual tabletop D&D, and that includes people that say they "love D&D".

I got into tabletop during 4e, tried to run games a few times, and the rules are way more complex than what the average person is willing to learn. I think that's changing now with games like Unstable Unicorns and junk becoming more popular via internet, but historically most people had never actually played games more complex than Monopoly or Scrabble.

So when video games came along saying they were "based on D&D" in the 90s and 2000s, they defined what a generation of kids thought of with D&D, and that was Real Time With Pause combat.

Before Critical Role, I think most people only knew of funny stories online like /tg/ where people talk about role playing a bear and rolling a nat 20 to sleep with a dragon. Critical Role, for better or worse, seemed to finally push actual true D&D into the public spotlight by presenting the game as an entertainment medium, a "game show" of sorts. So now it seems that more and more people are willing to sit down, read the Player's Handbook, and actually play the game... and then find out that basically none of the licensed video games from the past 30 years actually follow the real combat rules. I think the greater popularity of the real ruleset is why newer games like Baldur's Gate 3 and Solasta are the new hotness.

Just because an RPG is easy, that doesn't make it not an RPG. It just makes it an easy RPG.
